abase	"verb<br />behave in a way so as to belittle or degrade (someone) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">I watched my colleagues abasing themselves before the board of trustees.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Abase suggests groveling or a sense of inferiority and is usually used reflexively</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">got down on his knees and abased himself before the king</span><i>)</i>"
abash	"verb<br />cause to feel embarrassed, disconcerted, or ashamed : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">she was not abashed at being caught.</span> <br> <br>"
abate	"verb<br />(of something perceived as hostile, threatening, or negative) become less intense or widespread : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the storm suddenly abated.</span><br />• cause to become smaller or less intense : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">nothing abated his crusading zeal.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Abate suggests a progressive lessening in degree or intensity </span><span style=""color:#000000;"">(:</span><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">her fever was abating</span><span style=""color:#000000;"">).</span>"

abstract	"adjective<br />existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical or concrete existence : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">abstract concepts such as love or beauty.</span><br />• dealing with ideas rather than events : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the novel was too abstract and esoteric to sustain much attention.</span><br />• not based on a particular instance; theoretical : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">we have been discussing the problem in a very abstract manner.</span><br />• (of a word, esp. a noun) denoting an idea, quality, or state rather than a concrete object : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">abstract words like truth or equality.</span><br /><br />verb<br />1 consider (something) theoretically or separately from something else : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">to abstract science and religion from their historical context can lead to anachronism.</span><br />• form a general idea in this way : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he cannot form a general notion by abstracting from particulars.</span><br />2 extract or remove (something) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">applications to abstract more water from streams.</span><br />• used euphemistically to say that someone has stolen something : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">his pockets contained all he had been able to abstract from the apartment.</span><br />• ( abstract oneself) withdraw : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">as our relationship deepened you seemed to abstract yourself.</span><br />3 make a written summary of (an article or book) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">staff who index and abstract material for an online database.</span><br /><br />noun<br />1 a summary or statement of the contents of a book, article, or formal speech : <span style=""font-style:italic; the theoretical consideration of something : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the abstract must be made concrete by examples.</span> <br> <br>"

acute	"adjective<br />1 (of a bad, difficult, or unwelcome situation or phenomenon) present or experienced to a severe or intense degree : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">an acute housing shortage | the problem is acute and getting worse.</span><br />• (of a disease or its symptoms) of short duration but typically severe : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">acute appendicitis. Often contrasted with chronic .</span><br />• denoting or designed for patients with such conditions : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">acute hospital services | acute patients.</span><br />2 having or showing a perceptive understanding or insight; shrewd : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">an acute awareness of changing fashions. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">slow-witted</span><br />• (of a physical sense or faculty) highly developed; keen : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">an acute sense of smell. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">poor, weak</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Acute describes the intensification of a situation that is rapidly approaching a climax</span> (: <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">an acute shortage of O-negative blood</span>),<br /><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Acute is also close in meaning to keen, but with more emphasis on sensitivity and the ability to make subtle distinctions </span>(: <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">an acute sense of smell</span>)."

alacrity	"noun<br />brisk and cheerful readiness : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">she accepted the invitation with alacrity.</span> <br> <br>"
alchemy	"noun<br>the medieval forerunner of chemistry, based on the supposed transformation of matter. It was concerned particularly with attempts to convert base metals into gold or to find a universal elixir.<br>• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">figurative</span> a process by which paradoxical results are achieved or incompatible elements combined with no obvious rational explanation : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">his conducting managed by some alchemy to give a sense of fire and ice.</span> <br> <br>"
alcove	"noun<br />a recess, typically in the wall of a room or of a garden <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">from Arabic al-ḳubba ‘the vault.’</span>"
alias	"adverb<br>used to indicate that a named person is also known or more familiar under another specified name : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">Eric Blair, alias George Orwell.</span><br>• informal indicating another term or synonym : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the catfish—alias bullhead—is a mighty tasty fry-up.</span><br>noun<br>a false or assumed identity : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a spy operating under the alias Barsad.</span><br><br>verb <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">Physics &amp; Telecommunications</span><br>misidentify (a signal frequency), introducing distortion or error. <br> <br>"

annul	"verb<br />declare invalid (an official agreement, decision, or result) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the elections were annulled by the general amid renewed protests.</span><br />• declare (a marriage) to have had no legal existence : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">her first marriage was finally annulled by His Holiness.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">To void a check, to invalidate a claim, to abrogate a law, and to annul a marriage all refer to the same basic activity, which is putting an end to something or depriving it of validity, force, or authority. But these verbs are not always interchangeable.</span><br /><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Annul is the most general term, meaning to end something that exists or to declare that it never really existed </span><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#000000;"">(: </span><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the charter was annulled before it could be challenged</span><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#000000;"">).</span>"

archaic	"adjective<br>very old or old-fashioned : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">prisons are run on archaic methods.</span><br>• (of a word or a style of language) no longer in everyday use but sometimes used to impart an old-fashioned flavor.<br>• of an early period of art or culture, esp. the 7th–6th centuries bc in Greece: <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the archaic temple at Corinth.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Things rather than people are usually described as archaic, which means having the characteristics of an earlier, sometimes primitive, period</span> (: <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">archaic words like “thou” and “thine”</span>)."
archetype	"noun<br>a very typical example of a certain person or thing : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the book is a perfect archetype of the genre.</span><br>• an original that has been imitated : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the archetype of faith is Abraham.</span><br>• a recurrent symbol or motif in literature, art, or mythology : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">mythological archetypes of good and evil.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">While prototype and archetype are often used interchangeably, they really mean quite different things. An archetype is a perfect and unchanging form that existing things or people can approach but never duplicate </span>(: <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the archetype of a mother</span>), <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">while a prototype is an early, usually unrefined version of something that later versions reflect but may depart from</span> (: <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a prototype for a hydrogen-fueled car</span>)."

assiduous	"adjective<br>showing great care and perseverance : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">she was assiduous in pointing out every feature.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">The award for concentrated effort goes to the person who is assiduous, which suggests painstaking preoccupation with a specific task</span> (: <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">an assiduous student is the one most likely to win his or her teacher's favor</span>)."
assimilate	"verb<br />1 take in (information, ideas, or culture) and understand fully : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">Marie tried to assimilate the week's events.</span><br />• (usu. be assimilated) absorb and integrate (people, ideas, or culture) into a wider society or culture : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">pop trends are assimilated into the mainstream with alarming speed | [ intrans. ] the converts were assimilated into the society of their conquerors.</span><br />• absorb or integrate and use for one's own benefit : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the music business assimilated whatever aspects of punk it could turn into profit.</span><br />• (usu. be assimilated) (of the body or any biological system) absorb and digest (food or nutrients) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the sugars in the fruit are readily assimilated by the body.</span><br />2 cause (something) to resemble; liken : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">philosophers had assimilated thought to perception.</span><br />• come to resemble : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the churches assimilated to a certain cultural norm.</span> <br> <br>"
assuage	"verb<br />make (an unpleasant feeling) less intense : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the letter assuaged the fears of most members. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">aggravate, intensify</span><br />• satisfy (an appetite or desire) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">an opportunity occurred to assuage her desire for knowledge.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Assuage and allay both suggest the calming or satisfying of a desire or appetite, but assuage implies a more complete or permanent satisfaction</span> (: <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">we allay our hunger by nibbling hors d'oeuvres, but a huge dinner assuages our appetite</span>)."
assumption	"noun<br>1 a thing that is accepted as true or as certain to happen, without proof : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">they made certain assumptions about the market | [with clause ] we're working on the assumption that the time of death was after midnight.</span><br>2 the action of taking or beginning to take power or responsibility : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the assumption of an active role in regional settlements.</span> <br> <br>"
assurance	"noun<br>1 a positive declaration intended to give confidence; a promise : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">[with clause ] he gave an assurance that work would not recommence until Wednesday. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">self-doubt</span><br>2 confidence or certainty in one's own abilities : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">she drove with assurance. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">uncertainty</span><br>• certainty about something : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">assurance of faith depends on our trust in God.</span><br>3 <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">chiefly Brit.</span> insurance, specifically life insurance <br> <br>"

astigmatism	noun<br>a defect in the eye or in a lens caused by a deviation from spherical curvature, which results in distorted images, as light rays are prevented from meeting at a common focus. <br> <br>

An individual or a part that exhibits atavism.<br>3. The return of a trait or recurrence of previous behavior after a period of absence. <br> <br>

babble	"verb<br>talk rapidly and continuously in a foolish, excited, or incomprehensible way : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he would babble on in his gringo Spanish.</span><br>• utter something rapidly and incoherently : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">I gasped and stared and babbled, “Look at this!” | he began to babble an apology.</span><br>• reveal something secret or confidential by talking impulsively or carelessly :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> he babbled to another convict while he was in jail | my father babbled out the truth.</span><br>• (of a stream) make the continuous murmuring sound of water flowing over stones : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a gently babbling brook.</span><br>noun<br>the sound of people talking quickly and in a way that is difficult or impossible to understand : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a babble of protest.</span><br>• foolish, excited, or confused talk : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">her soft voice stopped his babble.</span><br>• [usu. in combination or with adj. ] pretentious jargon from a specified field : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">to shed light on such transatlantic psycho-babble.</span> <br> <br>"

ballast	"noun<br />1 heavy material, such as gravel, sand, iron, or lead, placed low in a vessel to improve its stability.<br />• a substance of this type carried in an airship or on a hot-air balloon to stabilize it, and jettisoned when greater altitude is required.<br />• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">figurative</span> something that gives stability or substance : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the film is an entertaining comedy with some serious ideas thrown in for ballast.</span><br />2 gravel or coarse stone used to form the bed of a railroad track or road.<br />• a mixture of coarse and fine aggregate for making concrete.<br />3 a passive component used in an electric circuit to moderate changes in current.<br /><br />verb (usu. be ballasted)<br />1 give stability to (a ship) by putting a heavy substance in its bilge :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> the vessel has been ballasted to give the necessary floating stability.</span><br />2 form (the bed of a railroad line or road) with gravel or coarse stone. <br> <br>"

baroque	"adjective<br>relating to or denoting a style of European architecture, music, and art of the 17th and 18th centuries that followed mannerism and is characterized by ornate detail. In architecture the period is exemplified by the palace of Versailles and by the work of Bernini in Italy. Major composers include Vivaldi, Bach, and Handel; Caravaggio and Rubens are important baroque artists.<br>• highly ornate and extravagant in style :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> the candles were positively baroque.</span> <br> <br>"

bereft	"<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">archaic</span> past participle of bereave.<br /><br />adjective<br />deprived of or lacking something, esp. a nonmaterial asset : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">her room was stark and bereft of color.</span><br />• (of a person) lonely and abandoned, esp. through someone's death or departure :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> his death in 1990 left her bereft.</span> <br> <br>"
berserk	"adjective<br />(of a person or animal) out of control with anger or excitement; wild or frenzied :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> after she left him, he went berserk, throwing things about the apartment.</span><br />• (of a mechanical device or system) operating in a wild or erratic way; out of control :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> the climate control went berserk and either roasted or froze us.</span><br />• (of a procedure, program, or activity) fluctuating wildly : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the stock market's gone berserk, with sugar at 15.27 cents a pound.</span> <br> <br>"
beseech	"verb <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">formal or literary</span><br />ask (someone) urgently and fervently to do something; implore; entreat : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">they beseeched him to stay | “You have got to believe me,” Gloria beseeched him | they earnestly beseeched his forgiveness | [as adj. ] a beseeching gaze.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Beseech also suggests urgency, as well as an emotional appeal</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he beseeched her to tell the truth</span><i>).</i>"
beset	"verb<br>1 (of a problem or difficulty) trouble or threaten persistently :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> the social problems that beset the inner city | she was beset with self-doubt | [as adj. ] poverty is a besetting problem.</span><br>• surround and harass; assail on all sides : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">I was beset by clouds of flies.</span><br>• hem in; enclose : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the ship was beset by ice.</span><br>2 ( be beset with) <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">archaic</span> be covered or studded with :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> blades of grass beset with glistening drops of dew.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Beset also means to attack on all sides</span> (: <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">beset by enemies</span>), <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">but it is also used frequently in other contexts to mean set or placed upon</span> (: <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a bracelet beset with diamonds</span>)."
besiege	"verb<br />surround (a place) with armed forces in order to capture it or force its surrender; lay siege to : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the guerrillas continued to besiege other major cities to the north | [as adj. ] the besieged city.</span><br />• crowd around oppressively; surround and harass : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">she spent the whole day besieged by newsmen.</span><br />• ( be besieged) be inundated by large numbers of requests or complaints : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the television station was besieged with calls.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Besiege means to surround with an armed force</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">to besiege the capital city</span><i>). </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">When used figuratively, its meaning comes close to that of assail, but with an emphasis on being hemmed in and enclosed rather than punished repeatedly </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">besieged with fears</span><i>).</i>"

bluff	"noun<br>an attempt to deceive someone into believing that one can or will do something : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the offer was denounced as a bluff | his game of bluff.</span><br>1 a steep cliff, bank, or promontory.<br><br>verb<br>try to deceive someone as to one's abilities or intentions : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he's been bluffing all along | “I am an accredited envoy,” he bluffed.</span><br>• mislead (someone) in this way : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the object is to bluff your opponent into submission.</span><br>• (in a card game) bet heavily on a weak hand in order to deceive opponents.<br>• ( bluff one's way) contrive a difficult escape or other achievement by maintaining a pretense :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> he bluffed his way onto an Antarctic supply vessel.</span><br><span style="" font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""></span><br><span style="" font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""><span style=""font-style:normal; color:#000000;"">adjective</span></span><br><span style="" color:#000000;"">direct in speech or behavior but in a good-natured way :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> a big, bluff, hearty man.</span></span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Someone who is bluff is usually more likable, possessing a frank, hearty manner that may be a little too outspoken but is seldom offensive</span> (: <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a bluff man who rarely minced words</span>)."

bolt	"noun<br>1 a metal pin or bar, in particular <br>• a bar that slides into a socket to fasten a door or window.<br>• a threaded pin that screws into a nut and is used to fasten things together.<br>• the sliding piece of the breech mechanism of a rifle.<br>• (in rock climbing) a long pin that is driven into a rock face so that a rope can be attached to it.<br>2 a short heavy arrow shot from a crossbow.<br>3 a flash of lightning leaving a jagged line across the sky.<br>verb<br>fasten (something) with a metal pin or bar, in particular<br>• fasten (a door or window) with a bar that slides into a socket :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> all the doors were locked and bolted.</span><br>• fasten (an object) to something else with a bolt : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the lid was put into position and bolted down | a camera was bolted to the aircraft.</span> <br> <br>"

complement	"noun<br>1 a thing that completes or brings to perfection :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> the libretto proved a perfect complement to the music.</span><br>2 a number or quantity of something required to make a group complete : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">at the moment we have a full complement of staff.</span><br>• the number of people required to crew a ship : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">almost half the ship's complement of 322 were wounded.</span><br><span style="" font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""></span><br><span style="" font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""><span style=""font-style:normal; color:#000000;"">verb</span></span><br><span style="" color:#000000;"">add to (something) in a way that enhances or improves it; make perfect <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">: a classic blazer complements a look that's stylish or casual.</span></span><br><span style="" font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""><span style=""font-style:normal; color:#000000;"">• add to or make complete</span> : the proposals complement the incentives already available.</span> <br> <br>"
complementary	"adjective<br />1 completing; forming a complement : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">backyard satellite dishes and the complementary electronic components.</span><br />• (of two or more different things) combining in such a way as to enhance or emphasize each other's qualities : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">three guitarists playing interlocking, complementary parts.</span><br /> <br> <br>"
compliance	"noun<br>1 the action or fact of complying with a wish or command : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">they must secure each other's cooperation or compliance.</span><br>• ( compliance with) the state or fact of according with or meeting rules or standards : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">all imports of timber are in compliance with regulations. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">violation</span><br>• unworthy or excessive acquiescence : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the appalling compliance with government views shown by the commission. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">defiance</span><br><span style="" font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""></span><br><span style="" font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""><span style=""font-style:normal; color:#000000;"">adjective</span></span><br><span style="" color:#000000;"">undertaken or existing mainly in order to comply with an earlier treaty, order, or law : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">WTO compliance legislation that ignores skyrocketing drug costs.</span></span> <br> <br>"

compound	"1 (often be compounded) make up (a composite whole); constitute : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a dialect compounded of Spanish and Dutch.</span><br />• mix or combine (ingredients or constituents) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">yellow pastas compounded with lemon zest or saffron.</span><br />• calculate (interest) on previously accumulated interest : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the yield at which the interest is compounded.</span><br />• (of a sum of money invested) increase by compound interest : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">let your money compound for five years.</span><br />2 make (something bad) worse; intensify the negative aspects of :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> I compounded the problem by trying to make wrong things right. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">alleviate</span> <br> <br>"

compromise	"noun<br />an agreement or a settlement of a dispute that is reached by each side making concessions : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">an ability to listen to two sides in a dispute, and devise a compromise acceptable to both | the secret of a happy marriage is compromise.</span><br />• a middle state between conflicting opinions or actions reached by mutual concession or modification :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> a compromise between communism and private enterprise.</span><br />• the acceptance of standards that are lower than is desirable : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">sexism should be tackled without compromise.</span><br /><br />verb<br />1 settle a dispute by mutual concession : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">in the end we compromised and deferred the issue.</span><br />•<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;""> archaic</span> settle (a dispute) by mutual concession :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> I should compromise the matter with my father.</span><br />2 weaken (a reputation or principle) by accepting standards that are lower than is desirable : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">commercial pressures could compromise safety.</span><br />• bring into disrepute or danger by indiscreet, foolish, or reckless behavior : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">situations in which his troops could be compromised.</span> <br> <br>"

confound	"verb<br>1 cause surprise or confusion in (someone), esp. by acting against their expectations : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the inflation figure confounded economic analysts.</span><br>• prove (a theory, expectation, or prediction) wrong : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the rise in prices confounded expectations.</span><br>• defeat (a plan, aim, or hope) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">we will confound these tactics by the pressure groups.</span><br>• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">archaic</span> overthrow (an enemy).<br>2 (often be confounded with) mix up (something) with something else so that the individual elements become difficult to distinguish : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">'nuke' is now a cooking technique, as microwave radiation is confounded with nuclear radiation.</span> <br> <br>"

congenial	"adjective<br>(of a person) pleasant because of a personality, qualities, or interests that are similar to one’s own : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">his need for some congenial company.</span><br>• (of a thing) pleasant or agreeable because suited to one’s taste or inclination : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he went back to a climate more congenial to his cold stony soul.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Something that is attractive gives pleasure because of its appearance or manner </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">an attractive house in a wooded setting</span><i>), </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">while congenial has more to do with compatibility</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a congenial couple</span><i>).</i>"
congenital	"adjective<br />(esp. of a disease or physical abnormality) present from birth :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> a congenital malformation of the heart. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">acquired</span><br />• (of a person) having a particular trait from birth or by firmly established habit : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a congenital liar.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Congenital also means from the time of one's birth, but it is primarily used in medical contexts and refers to problems or defects</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">congenital color-blindness; a congenital tendency toward schizophrenia</span><i>).</i>"
conglomerate	"noun<br />1 a number of different things or parts that are put together to form a whole but remain distinct entities : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the Earth is a specialized conglomerate of organisms.</span><br />• a large corporation formed by the merging of separate and diverse firms :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> a media conglomerate.</span><br /><br />adjective<br />of or relating to a conglomerate, esp. a large corporation : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">conglomerate businesses.</span> <br> <br>"
congruence	noun<br />correspondence of parts; harmonious relationship. <br> <br>
congruent	"adjective<br>1 in agreement or harmony : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">institutional and departmental objectives are largely congruent | the rules may not be congruent with the requirements of the law.</span><br>2 <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">Geometry</span> (of figures) identical in form; coinciding exactly when superimposed. <br> <br>"
conifer	noun<br>a tree that bears cones and evergreen needlelike or scalelike leaves. <br> <br>
conjecture	"noun<br>an opinion or conclusion formed on the basis of incomplete information : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">conjectures about the newcomer were many and varied | the purpose of the opening in the wall is open to conjecture.</span><br>• an unproven mathematical or scientific theorem : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the Goldbach conjecture.</span><br>• (in textual criticism) the suggestion or reconstruction of a reading of a text not present in the original source.<br><br>verb<br>form an opinion or supposition about (something) on the basis of incomplete information : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he conjectured the existence of an otherwise unknown feature | many conjectured that she had a second husband in mind.</span><br>• (in textual criticism) propose (a reading). <br> <br>"
conjugal	"adjective<br>of or relating to marriage or the relationship between husband and wife : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">conjugal loyalty.</span> <br> <br>"
conjure	"verb<br />1 make (something) appear unexpectedly or seemingly from nowhere as if by magic : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">Anne conjured up a most delicious homemade stew.</span><br />• call (an image) to mind : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">she had forgotten how to conjure up the image of her mother's face.</span><br />• (of a word, sound, smell, etc.) cause someone to feel or think of (something) :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> one scent can conjure up a childhood summer beside a lake.</span><br />• call upon (a spirit or ghost) to appear, by means of a magic ritual : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">they hoped to conjure up the spirit of their dead friend.</span> <br> <br>"
connivance	"noun<br />willingness to secretly allow or be involved in wrongdoing, esp. an immoral or illegal act : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">this infringement of the law had taken place with the connivance of officials.</span> <br> <br>"
connoisseur	"noun<br>an expert judge in matters of taste :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> a connoisseur of music.</span> <br> <br>"
connotation	"noun<br>an idea or feeling that a word invokes person in addition to its literal or primary meaning : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the word “discipline” has unhappy connotations of punishment and repression.</span><br>• the implication of such ideas or feelings : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the work functions both by analogy and by connotation.</span><br>• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">Philosophy</span> the abstract meaning or intension of a term, which forms a principle determining which objects or concepts it applies to.  <br> <br>"

conscientious	"adjective<br>(of a person) wishing to do what is right, esp. to do one's work or duty well and thoroughly :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> a conscientious and hardworking clerk. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">casual</span><br>• (of work or a person's manner) showing such an attitude : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a conscientious and purposeful look on her face.</span><br>• relating to a person's conscience : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the act does not provide exemption from service on the basis of personal conscientious beliefs.</span> <br> <br>"

consecrate	"verb (<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">usu be consecrated</span>)<br />make or declare (something, typically a church) sacred; dedicate formally to a religious or divine purpose : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the present Holy Trinity church was consecrated in 1845 | [as adj. ] consecrated ground.</span><br />• (in Christian belief) make (bread or wine) into the body or blood of Christ : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">[as adj. ] they received the host but not the consecrated wine.</span><br />• ordain (someone) to a sacred office, typically that of bishop :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> in 1969 he was consecrated bishop of Northern Uganda.</span><br />• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">informal</span> devote (something) exclusively to a particular purpose :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> they'd decided to consecrate all their energies to this purposeful act.</span> <br> <br>"

consistency	"noun<br>1 conformity in the application of something, typically that which is necessary for the sake of logic, accuracy, or fairness : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the grading system is to be streamlined to ensure greater consistency.</span><br>• the achievement of a level of performance that does not vary greatly in quality over time : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">his principal problem in tennis has been consistency.</span><br>2 the way in which a substance, typically a liquid, holds together; thickness or viscosity : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the sauce has the consistency of creamed butter.</span> <br> <br>"

consolidate	"verb<br>1 make (something) physically stronger or more solid : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the first phase of the project is to consolidate the outside walls.</span><br>• reinforce or strengthen (one's position or power) :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> the company consolidated its position in the international market.</span><br>• combine (a number of things) into a single more effective or coherent whole : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">all manufacturing activities have been consolidated in new premises.</span><br>• combine (a number of financial accounts or funds) into a single overall account or set of accounts.<br>• combine (two or more legal actions involving similar questions) into one for action by a court.<br>2 become stronger or more solid :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> the limy sands consolidate to sandy textured limestone.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Consolidate also implies a merger of distinct and separate elements, but the emphasis here is on achieving greater compactness, strength, or efficiency</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">consolidate their furnishings and buy a new house together</span><i>).</i>"

constituent	"adjective<br />1 being a part of a whole :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> the constituent minerals of the rock.</span><br />2 being a voting member of a community or organization and having the power to appoint or elect : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the constituent body has a right of veto.</span><br />• able to make or change a political constitution : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a constituent assembly.</span><br /><br />noun<br />1 a member of a constituency.<br />2 a component part of something : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the essential constituents of the human diet.</span><br />• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">Linguistics</span> the common part of two or several more complex forms, e.g., gentle in gentleman, gentlemanly, ungentlemanly. <br> <br>"
constraint	"noun<br>a limitation or restriction : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the availability of water is the main constraint on food production | time constraints make it impossible to do everything.</span><br>• stiffness of manner and inhibition in relations between people : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">they would be able to talk without constraint.</span> <br> <br>"
construe	"verb<br>interpret (a word or action) in a particular way : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">his words could hardly be construed as an apology. </span><br>• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">dated</span> analyze the syntax of (a text, sentence, or word) :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> both verbs can be construed with either infinitive.</span><br>• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">dated</span> translate (a passage or author) word for word, typically aloud. <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">To construe is to make a careful interpretation of something, especially where the meaning is ambiguous. For example, when a class misbehaves in front of a visitor, the teacher is likely to construe that behavior as an attempt to cause embarrassment or ridicule.</span>"

contaminate	"verb (often be contaminated)<br />make (something) impure by exposure to or addition of a poisonous or polluting substance : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the site was found to be contaminated by radioactivity | </span><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">figurative</span><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> the entertainment industry is able to contaminate the mind of the public | [as adj. ] contaminated blood products. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">purify</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">To contaminate is to spread harmful or undesirable impurities throughout something. Unlike pollute, which suggests visible or noticeable impurities, contaminate is preferred where the change is unsuspected or not immediately noticeable</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">milk contaminated by radioactive fallout from a nuclear plant accident</span><i>).</i>"

contingent	"adjective<br />1 subject to chance : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the contingent nature of the job.</span><br />• (of losses, liabilities, etc.) that can be anticipated to arise if a particular event occurs :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> businesses need to be aware of their liabilities, both actual and contingent.</span><br />• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">Philosophy</span> true by virtue of the way things in fact are and not by logical necessity : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">that men are living creatures is a contingent fact.</span><br />2 ( contingent on/upon) occurring or existing only if (certain other circumstances) are the case; dependent on : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">resolution of the conflict was contingent on the signing of a cease-fire agreement.</span><br /><br />noun<br />a group of people united by some common feature, forming part of a larger group : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a contingent of Japanese businessmen attending a conference.</span><br />• a body of troops or police sent to join a larger force in an operation : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a contingent of 2,000 marines.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">contingent points to something that is entirely dependent on an uncertain event for its existence or occurrence </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">travel plans that are contingent upon the weather</span><i>).</i>"

conundrum	"noun<br>a confusing and difficult problem or question :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> one of the most difficult conundrums for the experts.</span><br>• a question asked for amusement, typically one with a pun in its answer; a riddle. <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Conundrum applies specifically to a riddle phrased as a question, the answer to which usually involves a pun or a play on words, such as “What is black and white and read all over?”; conundrum can also refer to any puzzling or difficult situation.</span>"
convene	"verb<br>call people together for (a meeting) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he had convened a secret meeting of military personnel.</span><br>• assemble or cause to assemble for a common purpose : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he convened a group of well-known scientists and philosophers | the committee had convened for its final plenary session.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Convene is a formal word meaning to assemble or meet in a body</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">to convene an international conference on the subject of global warming</span><i>).</i>"
convention	"noun<br />1 a way in which something is usually done, esp. within a particular area or activity : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the woman who overturned so many conventions of children's literature.</span><br />• behavior that is considered acceptable or polite to most members of a society :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> he was an upholder of convention and correct form | social conventions.</span><br />2 an agreement between countries covering particular matters, esp. one less formal than a treaty.<br />3 a large meeting or conference, esp. of members of a political party or a particular profession : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a convention of retail merchants.</span><br />• (in the U.S.) an assembly of the delegates of a political party to select candidates for office.<br />• an organized meeting of enthusiasts for a television program, movie, or literary genre :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> a Star Trek convention.</span><br />• a body set up by agreement to deal with a particular issue : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the convention is a UN body responsible for the regulation of sea dumping.</span> <br> <br>"
conventional	"adjective<br />based on or in accordance with what is generally done or believed :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> a conventional morality had dictated behavior.</span><br />• (of a person) concerned with what is generally held to be acceptable at the expense of individuality and sincerity. <span style=""color:#008000;"">unorthodox, radical, Bohemian</span><br />• (of a work of art or literature) following traditional forms and genres : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">conventional love poetry.</span><br />• (of weapons or power) nonnuclear : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">agreement on reducing conventional forces in Europe.</span> <br> <br>"
converge	"verb<br>(of several people or things) come together from different directions so as eventually to meet : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">convoys from America and the UK traversed thousands of miles to converge in the Atlantic | figurative two separate people whose lives converge briefly from time to time.</span><br>• ( converge on/upon) come from different directions and meet at (a place) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">half a million sports fans will converge on the capital.</span><br>• (of a number of things) gradually change so as to become similar or develop something in common : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">two cultures converged as the French settled Vermont.</span><br>• (of lines) tend to meet at a point : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a pair of lines of longitude are parallel at the equator but converge toward the poles.</span> <br> <br>"
conversant	"adjective<br>familiar with or knowledgeable about something :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> many ladies are conversant with the merits of drill-eyed needles.</span> <br> <br>"
converse	"verb<br>engage in conversation : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he fell in beside her and they began to converse amicably.</span><br><br>noun<br>a situation, object, or statement that is the reverse of another, or that corresponds to it but with certain terms transposed : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">if spirituality is properly political, the converse is also true: politics is properly spiritual.</span><br>• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">Mathematics </span>a theorem whose hypothesis and conclusion are the conclusion and hypothesis of another.<br><br>adjective<br>having characteristics that are the reverse of something else already mentioned : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the slow process of growth and the converse process of decay.</span> <br> <br>"

dislodge	"verb<br>remove from an established or fixed position : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the hoofs of their horses dislodged loose stones | figurative this gripping race still offers the opportunity to dislodge the leader.</span> <br> <br>"
dismantle	"verb (often be dismantled)<br>take to pieces : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the engines were dismantled and the bits piled into a heap | </span><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">figurative</span><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> : the old regime was dismantled. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">assemble, build</span> <br> <br>"
dismember	"verb<br />cut off the limbs of (a person or animal) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">I can picture you in a white jacket dismembering rats | [as adj. ] he buried their dismembered bodies in the back yard.</span><br />• partition or divide up (a territory or organization) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">Russia intended to dismember the Ottoman Empire.</span> <br> <br>"
dismiss	"verb<br />order or allow to leave; send away : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">she dismissed the taxi at the corner of the road.</span><br />• discharge from employment or office : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">CBS Records dismissed another 120 people. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">engage</span><br />• treat as unworthy of serious consideration :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> it would be easy to dismiss him as all brawn and no brain.</span><br />• deliberately cease to think about : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he suspected a double meaning in her words, but dismissed the thought. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">entertain</span><br />• (of a group assembled under someone's authority) disperse : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he told his company to dismiss. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">assemble</span><br />• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">Law</span> refuse further hearing to (a case) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the judge dismissed the case for lack of evidence.</span><br />• (in sports) defeat or end an opponent’s turn. <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Dismiss is by far the mildest of these terms, suggesting that you are rejecting or refusing to consider someone or something </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">to dismiss a legal case)</span><i>. </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">It is also commonly used of loss of employment</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">dismissed from his job for excessive tardiness</span><i>)</i>"

dispatch	"noun<br />1 the sending of someone or something to a destination or for a purpose : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a resolution authorizing the dispatch of a peacekeeping force.</span><br />• speed in action : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the situation might change, so he should proceed with dispatch.</span><br />2 an official report on state or military affairs : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">in his battle dispatch he described the gunner's bravery.</span><br />• a report sent in by a newspaper's correspondent from a faraway place.<br />3 the killing of someone or something : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the legendary dispatch of villains by a hero.</span> <br> <br>"
dispel	"verb<br>make (a doubt, feeling, or belief) disappear : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the brightness of the day did nothing to dispel Elaine's dejection.</span><br>• drive (something) away; scatter : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">sprinkle catnip tea to dispel beetles from garden plants.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">To dispel is to scatter or to drive away something that obscures, confuses, or bothers </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">to dispel her fears</span><i>), </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">while to diffuse is to lessen the intensity of something by spreading it out over a broader area </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the curtains diffused the bright sunlight pouring in the window</span><i>).</i>"
disperse	"verb<br>distribute or spread over a wide area : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">storms can disperse seeds via high altitudes | camping sites could be dispersed among trees so as to be out of sight. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">assemble, gather</span><br>• go or cause to go in different directions or to different destinations : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the crowd dispersed | the police used tear gas to disperse the protesters.</span><br>• cause (gas, smoke, mist, or cloud) to thin out and eventually disappear : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">winds dispersed the bomb's radioactive cloud high in the atmosphere.</span><br>• thin out and disappear : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the earlier mist had dispersed.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Disperse implies a scattering that completely breaks up a mass or assemblage and spreads the units far and wide</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the crowd dispersed as soon as the storm arrived; the ships were so widely dispersed that they couldn't see each other</span><i>).</i>"

You can spend a lifetime disseminating knowledge, but you would broadcast the news of the birth of your first grandchild.</span>"

divine	"verb<br>discover (something) by guesswork or intuition : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">his brother usually divined his ulterior motives | [with clause ] they had divined that he was a fake.</span><br>• have supernatural or magical insight into (future events) :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> frauds who claimed to divine the future in chicken's entrails.</span><br>• discover (water) by dowsing.<br> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Divine and foreshadow mean to suggest the future rather than to predict it, especially by giving or evaluating subtle hints or clues. To divine something is to perceive it through intuition or insight </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">to divine in the current economic situation the disaster that lay ahead</span><i>), </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">while foreshadow can apply to anyone or anything that gives an indication of what is to come</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">her abrupt departure that night foreshadowed the breakdown in their relationship</span><i>).</i>"

dormant	"adjective<br>(of an animal) having normal physical functions suspended or slowed down for a period of time; in or as if in a deep sleep : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">dormant butterflies | </span><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">figurative</span><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> : the event evoked memories that she would rather had lain dormant.</span><br>• (of a plant or bud) alive but not actively growing.<br>• (of a volcano) temporarily inactive.<br>• (of a disease) causing no symptoms but not cured and liable to recur. <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Dormant and quiescent are less frequently associated with people and more often associated with things. A volcano might be described as dormant, which applies to anything that is currently inactive but has been active in the past and is capable of becoming active again in the future. Dormant carries the connotation of sleeping</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">plants that are dormant in the winter</span><i>), </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">while quiescent means motionless</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a quiescent sea</span><i>), </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">emphasizing inactivity without referring to past or future activity.</span>"

Effrontery is a more formal word for the flagrant disregard of the rules of propriety and courtesy </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">she had the effrontery to call the president by his first name</span><i>)</i>"

An epigram is a terse, witty, or satirical statement that often relies on a paradox for its effect </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">Oscar Wilde's well-known epigram that “The only way to get rid of temptation is to yield to it”</span><i>).</i>"

equivocate	"verb<br>use ambiguous language so as to conceal the truth or avoid committing oneself : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">“Not that we are aware of,” she equivocated.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Equivocate implies saying one thing and meaning another; it usually suggests the use of words that have more than one meaning, or whose ambiguity may be misleading. For example, if your spouse says, “Did you take care of the taxes today?” you might equivocate by saying “Yes,” you took care of them—meaning that you finished completing the forms and sealing them in the envelope, but that you didn't actually get them to the post office.</span>"

fallow	"adjective<br>(of farmland) plowed and harrowed but left unsown for a period in order to restore its fertility as part of a crop rotation or to avoid surplus production : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">incentives for farmers to let the land lie fallow in order to reduce grain surpluses.</span><br>• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">figurative</span> inactive : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">long fallow periods when nothing seems to happen.</span><br>• (of a sow) not pregnant. <br> <br>"
falter	"verb<br>start to lose strength or momentum : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">her smile faltered and then faded | [as adj. ] his faltering career.</span><br>• speak in a hesitant or unsteady voice : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">[with direct speech ] “I c-c-can't,” he faltered.</span><br>• move unsteadily or in a way that shows lack of confidence : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he faltered and finally stopped in midstride.</span> <br> <br>"
fanaticism	"noun<br>excessive zeal; extreme devotion to a belief or cause. <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">A fanatic is not only intense and eager but possibly irrational in his or her enthusiasm; fanatic suggests extreme devotion and a willingness to go to any length to maintain or carry out one's beliefs </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a fly-fishing fanatic who hired a helicopter to reach his favorite stream</span><i>).</i>"

ideology	"noun<br>1 a system of ideas and ideals, esp. one that forms the basis of economic or political theory and policy : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the ideology of republicanism.</span><br>• the ideas and manner of thinking characteristic of a group, social class, or individual :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> a critique of bourgeois ideology.</span><br>• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">archaic</span> visionary speculation, esp. of an unrealistic or idealistic nature.<br>2 <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">archaic</span> the science of ideas; the study of their origin and nature. <br> <br>"
idiom	"noun<br>1 a group of words established by usage as having a meaning not deducible from those of the individual words (e.g., rain cats and dogs, see the light).<br>• a form of expression natural to a language, person, or group of people :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> he had a feeling for phrase and idiom.</span><br>• the dialect of a people or part of a country.<br>2 a characteristic mode of expression in music or art : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">they were both working in a neo-Impressionist idiom.</span> <br> <br>"
idiosyncrasy	"noun<br>a mode of behavior or way of thought peculiar to an individual : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">one of his little idiosyncrasies was always preferring to be in the car first.</span><br>• a distinctive or peculiar feature or characteristic of a place or thing : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the idiosyncrasies of the prison system.</span><br>• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">Medicine </span>an abnormal physical reaction by an individual to a food or drug. <br> <br>"

Originally used of a genre of 14th-century Italian songs, the term now usually refers to English or Italian songs of the late 16th and early 17th c., in a free style strongly influenced by the text. <br> <br>

palliate	"verb<br>make (a disease or its symptoms) less severe or unpleasant without removing the cause :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> treatment works by palliating symptoms.</span><br>• allay or moderate (fears or suspicions) :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> this eliminated, or at least palliated, suspicions aroused by German unity.</span><br>• disguise the seriousness or gravity of (an offense) :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> there is no way to excuse or palliate his dirty deed.</span> <br> <br>"
pallid	"adjective<br>(of a person's face) pale, typically because of poor health.<br>• feeble or insipid : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">an utterly pallid and charmless character</span> <br> <br>"
palpable	"adjective<br />able to be touched or felt : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the palpable bump at the bridge of the nose. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">imperceptible</span><br />• (esp. of a feeling or atmosphere) so intense as to be almost touched or felt : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a palpable sense of loss.</span><br />• clear to the mind or plain to see : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">to talk of dawn raids in the circumstances is palpable nonsense.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Palpable, like tangible, means capable of being touched or felt </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a palpable mist)</span><i>, </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">but it is often applied to whatever evokes a tactile response from the body</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a palpable chill in the room</span><i>).</i>"

papyrus	noun<br>1 a material prepared in ancient Egypt from the pithy stem of a water plant, used in sheets throughout the ancient Mediterranean world for writing or painting on and also for making rope, sandals, and boats.<br>• a document written on papyrus. <br> <br>
parable	noun<br />a simple story used to illustrate a moral or spiritual lesson, as told by Jesus in the Gospels <br> <br>
paradigm	"noun<br />1 <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">technical </span>a typical example or pattern of something; a model : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">there is a new paradigm for public art in this country.</span><br />• a worldview underlying the theories and methodology of a particular scientific subject : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the discovery of universal gravitation became the paradigm of successful science.</span><br />2 a set of linguistic items that form mutually exclusive choices in particular syntactic roles : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">English determiners form a paradigm: we can say “a book” or “his book” but not “a his book.”</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Paradigm can refer to an example that serves as a model, but today its use is primarily confined to a grammatical context, where it means a set giving all the various forms of a word, such as the conjugation of a verb.</span>"
paradox	"noun<br>a statement or proposition that, despite sound (or apparently sound) reasoning from acceptable premises, leads to a conclusion that seems senseless, logically unacceptable, or self-contradictory : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a potentially serious conflict between quantum mechanics and the general theory of relativity known as the information paradox.</span><br>• a seemingly absurd or self-contradictory statement or proposition that when investigated or explained may prove to be well founded or true : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">in a paradox, he has discovered that stepping back from his job has increased the rewards he gleans from it.</span><br>• a situation, person, or thing that combines contradictory features or qualities : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">an Arizona canyon where the mingling of deciduous trees with desertic elements of flora forms a fascinating ecological paradox.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">A paradox is a statement that seems self-contradictory or absurd, but in reality expresses a possible truth</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">Francis Bacon's well-known paradox, “The most corrected copies are commonly the least correct”</span><i>).</i>"
paragon	"noun<br />a person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">it would have taken a paragon of virtue not to feel viciously jealous.</span><br />• a person or thing viewed as a model of excellence : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">your cook is a paragon.</span><br />• a perfect diamond of 100 carats or more. <br> <br>"
parallelism	noun<br>the state of being parallel or of corresponding in some way.<br>• the use of successive verbal constructions in poetry or prose that correspond in grammatical structure, sound, meter, meaning, etc.<br>• the use of parallel processing in computer systems. <br> <br>
parameter	"noun<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;""> technical</span><br />a numerical or other measurable factor forming one of a set that defines a system or sets the conditions of its operation : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the transmission will not let you downshift unless your speed is within the lower gear's parameters.</span><br />• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">Mathematics</span> a quantity whose value is selected for the particular circumstances and in relation to which other variable quantities may be expressed.<br />• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">Statistics </span>a numerical characteristic of a population, as distinct from a statistic of a sample.<br />• (in general use) a limit or boundary that defines the scope of a particular process or activity : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">they set the parameters of the debate.</span> <br> <br>"

paranoia	"noun<br>a mental condition characterized by delusions of persecution, unwarranted jealousy, or exaggerated self-importance, typically elaborated into an organized system. It may be an aspect of chronic personality disorder, of drug abuse, or of a serious condition such as schizophrenia in which the person loses touch with reality.<br>• suspicion and mistrust of people or their actions without evidence or justification : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the global paranoia about hackers and viruses.</span> <br> <br>"

precipitant	"noun<br>a cause of a particular action or event :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> the immediate precipitants of the conflict were a succession of undisciplined actions.</span><br>• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">chiefly Psychology</span> a cause or stimulus that precipitates a particular condition :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> depression may be a precipitant in many cases.</span><br>• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">Chemistry</span> a substance that causes the precipitation of a specified substance : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a protein precipitant.</span> <br> <br>"
precipitate	"verb<br>1 cause (an event or situation, typically one that is bad or undesirable) to happen suddenly, unexpectedly, or prematurely : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the incident precipitated a political crisis.</span><br>• cause to move suddenly and with force : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">suddenly the ladder broke, precipitating them down into a heap.</span><br>• ( precipitate someone/something into) send someone or something suddenly into a particular state or condition :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> they were precipitated into a conflict for which they were quite unprepared.</span><br>2 (usu. be precipitated) <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">Chemistry</span> cause (a substance) to be deposited in solid form from a solution.<br>• cause (drops of moisture or particles of dust) to be deposited from the atmosphere or from a vapor or suspension.<br><br>adjective<br>done, made, or acting suddenly or without careful consideration :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> I must apologize for my staff—their actions were precipitate.</span><br>• (of an event or situation) occurring suddenly or abruptly :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> a precipitate decline in cultural literacy.</span> <br> <br>"
precipitous	"adjective<br />1 dangerously high or steep : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the precipitous cliffs of the North Atlantic coast.</span><br />• (of a change to a worse situation or condition) sudden and dramatic : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the end of the war led to a precipitous decline in exports.</span><br />2 (of an action) done suddenly and without careful consideration : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">precipitous intervention.</span> <br> <br>"
precis	noun ( pl. same )<br>a summary or abstract of a text or speech. <br> <br>
precise	"adjective<br>marked by exactness and accuracy of expression or detail : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">precise directions | I want as precise a time of death as I can get. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">inaccurate</span><br>• (of a person) exact, accurate, and careful about details : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the director was precise with his camera positions.</span><br>• used to emphasize that one is referring to an exact and particular thing :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> at that precise moment the car stopped.</span><span style=""color:#008000;""> careless</span> <br> <br>"
preclude	"verb<br>prevent from happening; make impossible : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the secret nature of his work precluded official recognition.</span><br>• ( preclude someone from) (of a situation or condition) prevent someone from doing something : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">his difficulties preclude him from leading a normal life.</span> <br> <br>"
precocious	"adjective<br>(of a child) having developed certain abilities or proclivities at an earlier age than usual : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he was a precocious, solitary boy. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">backward</span><br>• (of behavior or ability) indicative of such development :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> a precocious talent for computing.</span><br>• (of a plant) flowering or fruiting earlier than usual. <br> <br>"
precursor	"noun<br>a person or thing that comes before another of the same kind; a forerunner : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a three-stringed precursor of the violin | [as adj. ] precursor cells.</span><br>•<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;""> Biochemistry</span> a substance from which another is formed, esp. by metabolic reaction : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">pepsinogen is the inactive precursor of pepsin.</span> <br> <br>"

predecessor	"noun<br>a person who held a job or office before the current holder : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the new president's foreign policy is very similar to that of his predecessor.</span><br>• a thing that has been followed or replaced by another : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the chapel was built in 1864 on the site of its predecessor.</span> <br> <br>"

preposterous	"adjective<br>contrary to reason or common sense; utterly absurd or ridiculous : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a preposterous suggestion. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">sensible</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Preposterous should be reserved for those acts or situations that are glaringly absurd or ludicrous. For example, it might be unreasonable to judge an entire nation on the basis of one tourist's experience and foolish to turn down an opportunity to visit that country on those grounds alone, but it would be preposterous to suggest that everyone who comes to the U.S. will be robbed at gunpoint.</span>"

presumptuous	"adjective<br>(of a person or their behavior) failing to observe the limits of what is permitted or appropriate :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> I hope I won't be considered presumptuous if I offer some advice. </span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Brazen implies a defiant lack of modesty</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a brazen stare</span><i>), </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">and presumptuous goes even further, suggesting overconfidence to the point of causing offense </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a presumptuous request for money</span><i>).</i>"

prevaricate	"verb<br />speak or act in an evasive way : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he seemed to prevaricate when journalists asked pointed questions. </span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">If you launch into a lengthy explanation of the day's frustrations and setbacks, the correct word would be prevaricate, which is to quibble, dodge the point, or confuse the issue so as to avoid telling the truth.</span>"
