progenitor	"noun<br>a person or thing from which a person, animal, or plant is descended or originates; an ancestor or parent : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">his sons and daughters were the progenitors of many of Scotland's leading noble families.</span><br>• a person who originates an artistic, political, or intellectual movement : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the progenitor of modern jazz.</span> <br> <br>"
progeny	"noun [treated as sing. or pl. ]<br>a descendant or the descendants of a person, animal, or plant; offspring : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the progeny of mixed marriages.</span> <br> <br>"
prognosis	"noun<br>the likely course of a disease or ailment : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the disease has a poor prognosis.</span><br>• a forecast of the likely course of a disease or ailment : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">it is very difficult to make an accurate prognosis.</span><br>• a forecast of the likely outcome of a situation : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">gloomy prognoses about overpopulation.</span> <br> <br>"
prognosticate	"verb<br />foretell or prophesy (an event in the future) : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the economists were prognosticating financial Armageddon. </span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Although anyone who has inside information or knowledge of signs and symptoms can prognosticate, it is usually a doctor who does so by looking at the symptoms of a disease to predict its future outcome.</span>"
prohibitive	"adjective<br />1 (of a price or charge) excessively high; difficult or impossible to pay : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the costs involved were prohibitive | prohibitive interest rates.</span><br />2 (esp. of a law or rule) forbidding or restricting something : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">prohibitive legislation.</span><br />• (of a condition or situation) preventing someone from doing something : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a wind over force 5 is prohibitive.</span> <br> <br>"
projectile	"noun<br>a missile designed to be fired from a rocket or gun.<br>• an object propelled through the air, esp. one thrown as a weapon : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">they tried to shield Johnson from the projectiles that were being thrown.</span><br><br>adjective<br>of or relating to such a missile or object :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> a projectile weapon.</span><br>• propelled with great force : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">projectile vomiting.</span> <br> <br>"
proletarian	"adjective<br />of or relating to the workers or working-class people : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a proletarian ideology.</span> <br> <br>"
proliferate	"verb<br>increase rapidly in numbers; multiply : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the science-fiction magazines which proliferated in the 1920s. </span><span style=""color:#008000;"">decrease, dwindle</span><br>• (of a cell, structure, or organism) reproduce rapidly :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> the Mediterranean faces an ecological disaster if the seaweed continues to proliferate at its present rate.</span><br>• cause (cells, tissue, structures, etc.) to reproduce rapidly : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">electromagnetic radiation can only proliferate cancers already present.</span><br>• produce (something) in large or increasing quantities : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the promise of new technology proliferating options on every hand</span> <br> <br>"
prolific	"adjective<br>1 (of a plant, animal, or person) producing much fruit or foliage or many offspring :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> in captivity, tigers are prolific breeders.</span><br>• (of an artist, author, or composer) producing many works : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he was a prolific composer of operas.</span><br>• (of a sports player) high-scoring : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a prolific home-run hitter.</span><br>2 present in large numbers or quantities; plentiful : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">mahogany was once prolific in the tropical forests.</span><br>• (of a river, area, or season of the year) characterized by plentiful wildlife or produce : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the prolific rivers and lakes of Franklin County.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">prolific is more usually applied to animals or plants in the literal sense of fertility, and suggests reproducing in great quantity or with rapidity. Figuratively, prolific is often used of highly productive creative efforts</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a prolific author with 40 titles published</span><i>).</i>"

prone	"adjective<br>1 ( prone to/prone to do something) likely to or liable to suffer from, do, or experience something, typically something regrettable or unwelcome : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">years of logging had left the mountains prone to mudslides | he is prone to jump to conclusions.</span><br>2 lying flat, esp. face downward : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">I was lying prone on a foam mattress | a prone position.</span><br>• <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">technical</span> denoting the position of the forearm with the palm of the hand facing downward.<br>3 <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#666666;"">archaic</span> with a downward slope or direction. <br> <br>"
propagate	"verb<br />1 breed specimens of (a plant, animal, etc.) by natural processes from the parent stock : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">try propagating your own houseplants from cuttings.</span><br />• (of a plant, animal, etc.) reproduce in such a way : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">the plant propagates freely from stem cuttings.</span><br />• cause (something) to increase in number or amount : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">operational error includes those errors propagated during the digitizing process.</span><br />2 spread and promote (an idea, theory, knowledge, etc.) widely :<span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> the French propagated the idea that the English were violent and gluttonous drunkards.</span><br />3 transmit (motion, light, sound, etc.) in a particular direction or through a medium : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">electromagnetic effects can be propagated at a finite velocity only through material substances | [as adj. ] a propagated electrical signal.</span><br />• (of motion, light, sound, etc.) be transmitted or travel in such a way : <span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a hydraulic fracture is generally expected to propagate in a vertical plane.</span> <br> <br>"

A volcano might be described as dormant, which applies to anything that is currently inactive but has been active in the past and is capable of becoming active again in the future. Dormant carries the connotation of sleeping</span><i> (:</i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> plants that are dormant in the winter</span><i>), </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">while quiescent means motionless</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a quiescent sea</span><i>), </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">emphasizing inactivity without referring to past or future activity</span><i>.</i>"

relinquish	"verb<br>voluntarily cease to keep or claim; give up : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">he relinquished his managerial role to become chief executive.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Of all these verbs meaning to let go or give up, relinquish is the most general. It can imply anything from simply releasing one's grasp </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">she relinquished the wheel</span><i>) </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">to giving up control or possession reluctantly</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">after the defeat, he was forced to relinquish his command</span><i>).</i>"

resonant	"adjective<br>(of sound) deep, clear, and continuing to sound or ring : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">a full-throated and resonant guffaw.</span><br>• <span style=""color:#666666;"">technical</span> of, relating to, or bringing about resonance in a circuit, atom, or other object.<br>• (of a room, a musical instrument, or a hollow body) tending to reinforce or prolong sounds, esp. by synchronous vibration.<br>• (of a color) enhancing or enriching another color or colors by contrast.<br>• ( resonant with) (of a place) filled or resounding with (the sound of something) : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">alpine valleys resonant with the sound of church bells.</span><br>• <span style=""color:#666666;"">figurative</span> having the ability to evoke or suggest enduring images, memories, or emotions : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">the prints are resonant with traditions of Russian folk art and story.</span> <br> <br>"
respiration	"noun<br>the action of breathing : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">opiates affect respiration.</span><br>• <span style=""color:#666666;"">chiefly Medicine</span> a single breath.<br>• <span style=""color:#666666;"">Biology </span>a process in living organisms involving the production of energy, typically with the intake of oxygen and the release of carbon dioxide from the oxidation of complex organic substances. <br> <br>"
respite	"noun<br />a short period of rest or relief from something difficult or unpleasant : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">the refugee encampments will provide some respite from the suffering | a brief respite from a dire food shortage.</span><br />• a short delay permitted before an unpleasant obligation is met or a punishment is carried out.<br /><br />verb <span style=""color:#666666;"">rare</span><br />postpone (a sentence, obligation, etc.) : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">the execution was only respited a few months.</span><br />• <span style=""color:#666666;"">archaic</span> grant a delay or extension of time to; reprieve from death or execution : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">some poor criminal … from the gibbet or the wheel, respited for a day.</span> <br> <br>"
resplendent	"adjective<br>attractive and impressive through being richly colorful or sumptuous : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">she was resplendent in a sea-green dress.</span> <br> <br>"
responsive	"adjective<br />1 reacting quickly and positively : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">a flexible service that is responsive to changing social and economic patterns.</span><br />• responding readily and with interest or enthusiasm : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">our most enthusiastic and responsive students.</span><br />2 answering : I'm distracted by a nibble on my line: <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">I jig it several times, but there is no responsive tug.</span><br />• (of a section of liturgy) using responses. <br> <br>"
restitution	"noun<br>1 the restoration of something lost or stolen to its proper owner : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">seeking the restitution of land taken from blacks under apartheid.</span><br>2 recompense for injury or loss : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">he was ordered to pay $6,000 in restitution.</span><br>3 the restoration of something to its original state : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">restitution of the damaged mucosa.</span><br>• <span style=""color:#666666;"">Physics</span> the resumption of an object's original shape or position through elastic recoil. <br> <br>"
restive	adjective<br>(of a person) unable to keep still or silent and becoming increasingly difficult to control, esp. because of impatience, dissatisfaction, or boredom.<br>• (of a horse) refusing to advance, stubbornly standing still or moving backward or sideways. <br> <br>
restraint	"noun<br>1 (often restraints) a measure or condition that keeps someone or something under control or within limits : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">decisions are made within the financial restraints of the budget.</span><br>• the action of keeping someone or something under control.<br>• deprivation or restriction of personal liberty or freedom of movement : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">he remained aggressive and required physical restraint.</span><br>• a device that limits or prevents freedom of movement :<span style=""color:#0000ff;""> car safety restraints.</span><br>2 unemotional, dispassionate, or moderate behavior; self-control : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">he urged the protestors to exercise restraint.</span><br>• understatement, esp. of artistic expression : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">with strings and piano, all restraint vanished.</span> <br> <br>"
resumption	"verb<br>begin to do or pursue (something) again after a pause or interruption : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">a day later normal service was resumed.</span><br>• begin to be done, pursued, or used again after a pause or interruption : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">hostilities had ceased and normal life had resumed.</span><br>• begin speaking again after a pause or interruption : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">he sipped at the glass of water on the lectern and then resumed | “As for Joe,” the major resumed, “I can't promise anything.”</span><br>• take, pick up, or put on again; return to the use of : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">the judge resumed his seat.</span> <br> <br>"

sting	"noun<br />1 a small sharp-pointed organ at the end of the abdomen of bees, wasps, ants, and scorpions, capable of inflicting a painful or dangerous wound by injecting poison.<br />• any of a number of minute hairs or other organs of plants, jellyfishes, etc., that inject a poisonous or irritating fluid when touched.<br />• a wound from such an animal or plant organ : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">a wasp or bee sting.</span><br />• a sharp tingling or burning pain or sensation : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">I felt the sting of the cold, bitter air.</span><br />• <span style=""color:#666666;"">figurative</span> a hurtful quality or effect : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">she smiled to take the sting out of her words.</span><br />2 <span style=""color:#666666;"">informal</span> a carefully planned operation, typically one involving deception :<span style=""color:#0000ff;""> five blackmailers were jailed last week after they were snared in a police sting.</span><br /><br />verb<br />1 wound or pierce with a sting : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">he was stung by a jellyfish | a nettle stings if you brush it lightly.</span><br />2 feel or cause to feel a sharp tingling or burning pain or sensation : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">her eyes stung | the brandy stung his throat | [as adj. ] a stinging pain.</span><br />• <span style=""color:#666666;"">figurative</span> (typically of something said) hurt or upset (someone) : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">stung by her mockery, Frank hung his head.</span><br />• ( sting someone into) provoke someone to do (something) by causing annoyance or offense :<span style=""color:#0000ff;""> he was stung into action by an article in the paper.</span><br />3 <span style=""color:#666666;"">informal </span>swindle or exorbitantly overcharge (someone) : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">an elaborate fraud that stung a bank for thousands.</span> <br> <br>"

transitory	"adjective<br>not permanent :<span style=""color:#0000ff;""> transitory periods of medieval greatness.</span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">transitory refers to something that is destined to pass away or come to an end</span><i> (:</i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;""> the transitory pleasure of eating</span><i>).</i>"
translucent	"adjective<br>(of a substance) allowing light, but not detailed images, to pass through; semitransparent : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">fry until the onions become translucent.</span> <br> <br>"
transmute	"verb<br>change in form, nature, or substance : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">the raw material of his experience was transmuted into stories | the discovery that elements can transmute by radioactivity.</span><br>• subject (base metals) to alchemical transmutation : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">the quest to transmute lead into gold.</span> <br> <br>"
transparent	"adjective<br>(of a material or article) allowing light to pass through so that objects behind can be distinctly seen :<span style=""color:#0000ff;""> transparent blue water.</span><br>• easy to perceive or detect : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">the residents will see through any transparent attempt to buy their votes | the meaning of the poem is by no means transparent.</span><br>• having thoughts, feelings, or motives that are easily perceived :<span style=""color:#0000ff;""> you'd be no good at poker—you're too transparent.</span><br>• (of an organization or its activities) open to public scrutiny :<span style=""color:#0000ff;""> if you had transparent government procurement, corruption would go away.</span> <br> <br>"
transpire	"verb<br />1 occur; happen :<span style=""color:#0000ff;""> I'm going to find out exactly what transpired.</span><br />• prove to be the case : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">as it transpired, he was right.</span><br />• (usu. it transpires) (of a secret or something unknown) come to be known; be revealed :<span style=""color:#0000ff;""> Yaddo, it transpired, had been under FBI surveillance for some time.</span><br />2 <span style=""color:#666666;"">Botany</span> (of a plant or leaf) give off water vapor through the stomata. <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Transpire is a more formal (and some would say undesirable) word meaning to happen or occur, and it conveys the sense that something has leaked out or become known </span><i>(: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">he told her exactly what had transpired while she was away)</span><i>.</i>"
transport	"noun<br>(usu. transports) an overwhelmingly strong emotion : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">art can send people into transports of delight. </span> <br> <br><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#e50025;"">Transport applies to any powerful emotion by which one is carried away</span><i> (: </i><span style=""font-style:italic; color:#0000ff;"">a transport of delight</span><i>).</i>"

repose	"noun<br>temporary rest from activity, excitement, or exertion, esp. sleep or the rest given by sleep :<span style=""color:#0000ff;""> in repose her face looked relaxed.</span><br>• a state of peace : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">the repose of the soul of the dead man.</span><br>• composure : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">he had lost none of his grace or his repose.</span><br>• <span style=""color:#666666;"">Art</span> harmonious arrangement of colors and forms, providing a restful visual effect.<br><br>verb<br>be lying, situated, or kept in a particular place : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">the diamond now reposes in the Louvre.</span><br>• lie down in rest : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">how sweetly he would repose in the four-poster bed.</span><br>• ( repose something on/in) poetic/literary lay something to rest in or on (something) :<span style=""color:#0000ff;""> I'll go to him, and repose our distresses on his friendly bosom.</span><br>• <span style=""color:#666666;"">archaic</span> give rest to : <span style=""color:#0000ff;"">he halted to repose his wayworn soldiers.</span> <br> <br>"
